Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Perioperative Systemic Therapy Versus CRS–HIPEC Alone in Resectable Colorectal Peritoneal Metastases

Participants.evidence: eligible patients were adults with isolated resectable colorectal peritoneal metastases. Conducted in nine Dutch tertiary hospitals

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to either perioperative systemic therapy or CRS–HIPEC alone

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare patient-reported outcomes (PROs)

Method_Outcome.evidence: PROs were assessed using EORTC QLQ-C30, QLQ-CR29, and EQ-5D-5L questionnaires at baseline, after neoadjuvant treatment, and at 3 and 6 months postoperatively

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by previous systemic therapy, onset of peritoneal metastases, peritoneal cancer index, and planned HIPEC regimen

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between June 2017 and January 2019, 80 patients were randomised, with 40 in each group

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the modified intention-to-treat analysis, 37 patients received perioperative systemic therapy and 42 underwent upfront surgery

Result_Outcome.evidence: All predefined PROs were comparable between arms at all timepoints and returned to baseline at 3 or 6 months postoperatively

Harms.evidence: The experimental arm showed worsening of fatigue (MD +14, p = 0.001), loss of appetite (MD +15, p = 0.003), hair loss (MD +18, p < 0.001), and loss of taste (MD +27, p < 0.001)
